On Wed, 11 Jun 2003 18:26:20 -0400, "J. B. Rainsberger"
<jbrains@...> said:
> You could also try reading the question. :) :) :)  That looks
> suspiciously like using a get method.

Well deserved...  I will answer less hastily in the future.
 
> To the OP, there are a number of ways to answer that question, depending
> on the actual design under test. If you can give us some information on
> what the 'void' method does, we may have a suggestion for you.

I think JB's point of knowing what the void method is supposed to do is a
good one.  You don't have to give code, you could give psuedo-code.  In
turn the answers you receive would probably be much better suited to you.

The general Observer/Observable pattern that JB referred to is good. 
However, that may introduce unnecessary overhead.  Every void method must
have some side effect on the system, otherwise it does nothing.  In
general, you should test for the side effect.  Though I gave an answer
with a getter, the point remains the same.

Testing a logger is a good example.  Most likely the interface into the
logger is comprised of void methods (eg. debug(Object), info(Object),
trace(Object), etc.).  However, that logger must log out to something. 
If you design it well enough you should be able to attach an arbitrary
stream to the logger and check the stream for the contents you think
should be logged.

For a code example of testing void methods, you could also look at the
last several issues of Software Development magazine where Bob Martin is
continuing a series on Test Driven Development.  As I recall, there are
some void methods in the server they are writing that are being tested
without getters... but I could be wrong. :)

=jason
--

=jason
